articles.headline: China Tries to Extract Pledge of Compliance From U.S. Tech Firms
articles.snippet: Some have received letters asking for a promise to make their products “secure and controllable,” a catchphrase that might mean backdoor access to private information.
articles.abstract: Some have received letters asking for a promise to make their products “secure and controllable,” a catchphrase that might mean backdoor access to private information.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government, which has long used its country’s vast market as leverage over American technology companies, is now asking some of those firms to directly pledge their commitment to contentious policies that could require them to turn user data and intellectual property over to the government.

articles.headline: U.S. Said to Have Settled With G.M. Over Deadly Defect
articles.snippet: The deal would be in the form of a deferred-prosecution agreement, and include a penalty just under $1 billion. But no G.M. employees are expected to be indicted.
articles.abstract: The deal would be in the form of a deferred-prosecution agreement, and include a penalty just under $1 billion. But no G.M. employees are expected to be indicted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are poised to settle a criminal investigation into General Motors, according to people briefed on the matter, accusing the automaker of failing to disclose a safety defect tied to at least 124 deaths. The case, which the prosecutors plan to unveil on Thursday, would cap a wide-ranging investigation that tainted the automaker’s reputation for quality and safety and damaged its bottom line.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Altice in Deal to Take Over Cablevision
articles.snippet: The transaction would further realign an industry already in upheaval as cable and telecom companies seek greater scale and negotiating power with content providers.
articles.abstract: The transaction would further realign an industry already in upheaval as cable and telecom companies seek greater scale and negotiating power with content providers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cablevision has agreed to sell itself to Altice, an acquisitive European telecommunications giant, for about $17.7 billion, including debt, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday. It is the latest deal to reshape the broadband and cable television landscape.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Bank of America’s Fight to Keep Brian Moynihan’s Dual Roles
articles.snippet: Bank of America shareholders will vote on Tuesday on whether Brian T. Moynihan can retain his role as both chairman and C.E.O.
articles.abstract: Bank of America shareholders will vote on Tuesday on whether Brian T. Moynihan can retain his role as both chairman and C.E.O.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forget the Iowa caucuses or the New Hampshire primary. One of the more intense and dogged campaigns is currently being waged by Bank of America to convince shareholders that Brian T. Moynihan should keep his job as both chairman and chief executive.

articles.headline: Putin Sees Path to Diplomacy Through Syria
articles.snippet: The Russian president unleashed a diplomatic offensive this week, pushing to meet with President Obama, and planning a big rollout for a Syrian peace plan at the United Nations.
articles.abstract: The Russian president unleashed a diplomatic offensive this week, pushing to meet with President Obama, and planning a big rollout for a Syrian peace plan at the United Nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — To much of the world, Syria is a scene of unending tragedy, but to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia it is a golden opportunity, a way out of the isolation he and Russia have endured since the West imposed sanctions over Ukraine — with the added bonus of wagging an “I told you so” finger at the White House.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Candidates Use Second G.O.P. Debate to Taunt Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Several Republican candidates showed new aggressiveness in lacing into Donald J. Trump on Wednesday night, using their latest televised debate to shame, criticize and mock him.
articles.abstract: Several Republican candidates showed new aggressiveness in lacing into Donald J. Trump on Wednesday night, using their latest televised debate to shame, criticize and mock him.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — Determined to prove their mettle, several Republican presidential candidates showed new aggressiveness in lacing into Donald J. Trump on Wednesday night, seeking to elevate themselves as leaders of substance and shake up a race that Mr. Trump has dominated all summer.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: A New Stage but a Familiar Donald Trump: The Brawler
articles.snippet: As became clear within minutes, there would be no new Donald Trump taking the stage at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library on Wednesday night.
articles.abstract: As became clear within minutes, there would be no new Donald Trump taking the stage at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library on Wednesday night.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump arrived at the second Republican presidential debate dominating the field but facing a critical question: Would he use the moment to move beyond attention-grabbing theatrics and present himself as a candidate many voters could envision as the party’s nominee — not to mention as president of the United States?

articles.headline: Post-Deal Iran Asks if U.S. Is Still ‘Great Satan,’ or Something Less
articles.snippet: Since the nuclear pact was reached, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and President Hassan Rouhani have offered starkly opposing visions of Iran’s future relationship with the United States.
articles.abstract: Since the nuclear pact was reached, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and President Hassan Rouhani have offered starkly opposing visions of Iran’s future relationship with the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A new struggle is unfolding in Iran, where the top leaders have begun to tackle the question of how to deal with the United States after having reached a nuclear agreement with their great enemy.

articles.headline: Germany Works to Get Migrants Jobs
articles.snippet: Germany is pushing for migrants to get into work as quickly as possible to speed their assimilation into German society, despite fears that migrants will “steal” jobs or lower wages.
articles.abstract: Germany is pushing for migrants to get into work as quickly as possible to speed their assimilation into German society, despite fears that migrants will “steal” jobs or lower wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASSAU, Germany — As Germany struggles with a surge of migrants and has at least temporarily clamped down on new arrivals, Nematullah Jasor may serve as a symbol of the way forward.

articles.headline: John Boehner, Strong Abortion Foe, Is Imperiled by the Like-Minded
articles.snippet: The House speaker faces pressure to stand up to President Obama over federal funding for Planned Parenthood, even if it means a government shutdown.
articles.abstract: The House speaker faces pressure to stand up to President Obama over federal funding for Planned Parenthood, even if it means a government shutdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner has been a luminary in the anti-abortion movement since he was a little-known Ohio state lawmaker, and is widely viewed as the most passionate opponent of abortion ever to wield the speaker’s gavel.

articles.headline: Carly Fiorina Offers Republicans a Pathway to Reach Women
articles.snippet: Mrs. Fiorina’s solid debate performance on Wednesday could help lessen a problem that her party has struggled with: how to better entice female voters.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Fiorina’s solid debate performance on Wednesday could help lessen a problem that her party has struggled with: how to better entice female voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a debate performance that was steely and at times deeply personal, Carly Fiorina appears to have improved her standing in the race to be the Republican nominee. But even if she falls short, she took a big stride toward filling a role her party badly needs: a credible antidote to the gender gap and the Democrats’ claims of a Republican “war on women.”

articles.headline: Trump Lands a Blow Against Carried Interest Tax Loophole
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump singled out the loophole, which primarily benefits Wall Street titans, as “ridiculous.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump singled out the loophole, which primarily benefits Wall Street titans, as “ridiculous.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Give Donald Trump credit for this: The Republican presidential candidate has done more to put a stake in the heart of the carried-interest tax loophole in the last month than the Obama administration has in the last six and a half years.

articles.headline: $900 Million Penalty for G.M.’s Deadly Defect Leaves Many Cold
articles.snippet: In a settlement, no individual employees were charged, and the Justice Department agreed to defer prosecution of G.M. for three years.
articles.abstract: In a settlement, no individual employees were charged, and the Justice Department agreed to defer prosecution of G.M. for three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the number of deaths linked to defective cars made by General Motors has steadily risen to 124, victims’ families have waited for the answer to a burning question: How will federal prosecutors hold the automaker accountable for its decade-long failure to disclose the defect?
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Bill Vlasic
